div.p: S. I arrived here later than I had planned because, when I wanted to leave Solothurn, I was seized by colic, which tormented me in a remarkable way for three days; but I have finally recovered. Here, I found not a bad beginning of pacification and the people of the Five Cantons finally brought to the point that they accept the path of justice. I will speak privately and familiarly with their envoys and freely reveal to them what I think about this whole matter and their obstinacy. The Lord sometimes allows that, while some provinces enjoy peace after the long inconveniences of wars, others, which have been quiet for a very long time, are set ablaze by foreign or civil wars. Such are the vicissitudes; but those who revere the Lord are preserved, and they enjoy the benefits of peace in Him and also move what is necessary. I am convinced that I will leave nothing undone in this pacification.

My wife sends you some condiments and cheeses sent to me from the Dauphin√©, which are not bad; you will receive them with a benevolent spirit and love us. I received your three bundles of letters with the leaves, which are most welcome to me.
The letters will be safely delivered to the one who is in the household of the King of Navarre.

The authority of this king increases daily, from which many conceive good hope. I am waiting to see what has been concluded in the assemblies, only I fear that peace may not be established among the princes of France. There would be a need for a firmer amnesty than the one that was after Caesar was killed.
There are various rumors about Philip's death, but still without an author. Greet all friends.
May the Lord keep you safe.
To Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, proclaimer of the word of God in Zurich, to be delivered safely. Together with a package covered with linen cloth.
